sourcesContent:
import logo from './logo.svg'; import './App.css'; function App() { return (

1. Overview

Purpose:

Teach users to solve simple deductive logic puzzles (e.g. “Who owns the zebra?”–style grid puzzles) by presenting a series of clues, gathering answers, and adapting difficulty.

target audience is beginners with no formal logic training,

core features are user authentication (login), lesson flow, clue presentation, userinput, immediate feedback

adaptive difficulty based on performance, and performance analytics dashboard

2. data models

User id (PK), username, email, hashed_password, current_level

Puzzle id (PK), title, description (text of the puzzle scenario), difficulty_level (1–5)

Clue id (PK), puzzle_id (FK), text (single clue), order

Question id (PK), puzzle_id (FK), prompt (e.g. “Who owns the zebra?”), answer_type (text or multiple‑choice), correct_answer

Attempt id (PK), user_id (FK), question_id (FK), submitted_answer, is_correct (bool), timestamp

3. User flows

3.1 Registration / login

Register: User submits username, email, password → back end validates & hashes → returns JWT.

Login: User submits username/email & password → back end verifies → returns JWT.

3.2 Lesson Flow

Fetch Puzzle: Front end requests GET /api/puzzles?level=current_level → back end returns one puzzle object (including its clues and questions).

Answer Questions: For each question in the puzzle:Render input (text field or MCQ).On submit, POST to /api/attempts.

show immediate feedback, such as correct, or try again

Complete Puzzle: Once all questions answered correctly, show success message and “Next Puzzle” button.

); } export default App;
